title: 106_s2310
content: The "Firearms Dealer Penalty Flexibility Act of 2000" allows for the suspension of a firearms dealer's license and imposes civil penalties. Section 923 of title 18, United States Code, allows the Secretary to suspend or revoke a license or impose civil penalties up to $10,000 for willful violations of firearm regulations. The Secretary has the authority to suspend or revoke a dealer's license, impose civil penalties up to $10,000, and compromise, mitigate, or remit liability for willful violations of firearm regulations. The Secretary has the authority to suspend or revoke a dealer's license, impose civil penalties up to $10,000, and compromise, mitigate, or remit liability for willful violations of firearm regulations. An action of the Secretary under this subsection may be reviewed only as provided in subsection (f), which outlines the rights of applicants and licensees in case of denial, revocation, suspension, or assessment of civil penalties. The Secretary must provide written notice of denial, revocation, suspension, or assessment to the affected party, stating specific grounds and giving notice before the effective date. An appeal process with a hearing is available if the Secretary denies an application. The Secretary must hold a hearing upon request to review denial, revocation, suspension, or assessment of a license. After a hearing, if the Secretary decides not to reverse the denial, revocation, suspension, or penalty, notice of the decision must be provided to the aggrieved party within a 60-day appeal period. During the 60-day appeal period, the aggrieved party can file a petition for judicial review in the district court for a de novo review of the decision. In a judicial proceeding, the court can consider evidence submitted by parties regardless of whether it was presented at the initial hearing. If the court determines that the Secretary was not authorized, actions like revocation, suspension, or assessment may be challenged. If the court decides that the Secretary was not authorized, actions like revocation, suspension, or assessment may be challenged, and the court can order necessary compliance. Upon request, the Secretary will delay the revocation, suspension, or penalty of a license pending an appeal. Section 925(b) of title 18, United States Code, is amended to terminate a firearms dealer's license upon felony conviction.
